bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Goodwin, May 11, 1706

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant John Goodwin, May 11, 1706, referring to an earlier letter in which he had notified Goodwin of a bill of exchange drawn on him on the account of the estate of Ralph Wormeley, and now alerts him to another bill given to a ship's caoptain, and that he sends a bill of lading for tobacco belonging to the estate on board the Mansfield.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Goodwin, May 11, 1706

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
[May 11, 1706]
Mr. John Good[win]

div1.p:
My last to you relating to the Estate of Esq[r Wormeley told]
you tht I had drawn on you for Seventy nine pounds [to Mr.]
Churchill Esqr. being [ . . . ] for Negroes I bot of him for [the use of the]
Estate I've Since drawn on you for Two pounds Twe[lve shillings]
to Capt Burford for Impost & Coqt money I desire [you to make]
payment of these Sums & charge the sd Estate —

herewth Send you a Bill of Lading for 20 hhds [of tobacco per the]
Mansfeild in the dispose whereof I desire you [to use great]
care for the Advantage of the Orphans
div1.closer:
I remain
Sr Yor h[umble Servt]

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783, and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 169. This undated letter was copied into the letter book with others of this date.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.
